<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 390, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 7 Probability & Statistics 2 (S2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 392, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 352, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 368, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 325, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 284, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 590, 509]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 510, 606, 525]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 540, 606, 555]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 556, 756, 571]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 572, 440, 587]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
The number of new enquiries per day at an office has a Poisson distribution. In the past the mean has been 3. Following a change of staff, the manager wishes to test, at the \(5\%\) significance level, whether the mean has increased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 135, 148, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 135, 579, 153]]<|/det|>
State the null and alternative hypotheses for this test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 917, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 920, 200]]<|/det|>
The manager notes the number, \(N\), of new enquiries during a certain 6-day period. She finds that \(N = 25\) and then, assuming that the null hypothesis is true, she calculates that \(\mathrm{P}(N \geqslant 25) = 0.0683\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 214, 151, 231]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 214, 438, 231]]<|/det|>
What conclusion should she draw?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 214, 917, 231]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 259, 97, 278]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 259, 920, 293]]<|/det|>
A population has mean 7 and standard deviation 3. A random sample of size \(n\) is chosen from this population.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 306, 151, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 306, 828, 324]]<|/det|>
Write down the mean and standard deviation of the distribution of the sample mean.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 306, 917, 324]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 337, 153, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 337, 593, 355]]<|/det|>
Under what circumstances does the sample mean have

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 362, 171, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 362, 371, 380]]<|/det|>
a normal distribution,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 362, 917, 380]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 387, 505, 406]]<|/det|>
b) an approximately normal distribution?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 387, 917, 406]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 432, 96, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 432, 803, 451]]<|/det|>
In a sample of 50 students at Batlin college, 18 support the football club Real Madrid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 464, 151, 483]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 464, 920, 497]]<|/det|>
Calculate an approximate \(98\%\) confidence interval for the proportion of students at Batlin college who support Real Madrid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 510, 153, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 551, 528]]<|/det|>
Give one condition for this to be a reliable result.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 510, 917, 528]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 556, 94, 575]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 556, 920, 590]]<|/det|>
Bacteria of a certain type are randomly distributed in the water in two ponds, \(A\) and \(B\). The average numbers of bacteria per \(\text{cm}^3\) in \(A\) and \(B\) are 0.32 and 0.45 respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 603, 148, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 603, 920, 636]]<|/det|>
Samples of \(8 \mathrm{cm}^3\) of water from \(A\) and \(12 \mathrm{cm}^3\) of water from \(B\) are taken at random. Find the probability that the total number of bacteria in these samples is at least 3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 621, 917, 638]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 650, 153, 668]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 650, 920, 683]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that in a random sample of \(155 \mathrm{cm}^3\) of water from \(A\), the number of bacteria is less than 35.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 667, 917, 685]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 712, 94, 731]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 712, 920, 761]]<|/det|>
Fiona and Jhoti each take one shower per day. The times, in minutes, taken by Fiona and Jhoti to take a shower are represented by the independent variables \(F \sim \mathrm{N}(12.2, 2.8^2)\) and \(J \sim \mathrm{N}(11.8, 2.6^2)\) respectively. Find the probability that, on a randomly chosen day,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 769, 151, 787]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 769, 737, 787]]<|/det|>
the total time taken to shower by Fiona and Jhoti is less than 30 minutes,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 769, 917, 787]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 794, 153, 812]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 794, 625, 812]]<|/det|>
Fiona takes at least twice as long as Jhoti to take a shower.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 794, 920, 812]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
At a certain shop the weekly demand, in kilograms, for flour is modelled by the random variable \(X\) with probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 112, 616, 163]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}k x^{-\frac{1}{2}} & 4\leqslant x\leqslant 25,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 292, 184]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 197, 156, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 197, 292, 215]]<|/det|>
Show that \(k = \frac{1}{6}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 198, 920, 215]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 227, 153, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 227, 609, 246]]<|/det|>
Calculate the mean weekly demand for flour at the shop.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 228, 920, 247]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 259, 151, 277]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 259, 920, 293]]<|/det|>
At the beginning of one week, the shop has \(20\mathrm{kg}\) of flour in stock. Find the probability that this will not be enough to meet the demand for that week.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 274, 920, 293]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 305, 151, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 305, 559, 324]]<|/det|>
Give a reason why the model may not be realistic.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 306, 920, 324]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 351, 94, 370]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 920, 402]]<|/det|>
The weights, \(X\) kilograms, of bags of carrots are normally distributed. The mean of \(X\) is \(\mu\) . An inspector wishes to test whether \(\mu = 2.0\). He weighs a random sample of 200 bags and his results are summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 403, 606, 422]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma x = 430\qquad \Sigma x^{2} = 1290\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 439, 153, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 439, 541, 458]]<|/det|>
Carry out the test, at the \(10\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 440, 920, 458]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 470, 153, 489]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 470, 920, 504]]<|/det|>
You may now assume that the population variance of \(X\) is 1.85. The inspector weighs another random sample of 200 bags and carries out the same test at the \(10\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 510, 185, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 510, 609, 529]]<|/det|>
State the meaning of a Type II error in this context.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 510, 920, 529]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 536, 186, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 536, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mu = 2.12\), show that the probability of a Type II error is 0.652, correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]
